transcripts.text: One of the striking things about recent politics is how the middle class seem to have become thoroughly left wing.  It was notable that as they lost their heartlands in the north of England in the general election, the Labour Party's only gain was in Putney, an area in which the median wage is £70,000.  I have long had a theory that what we are seeing is not a political phenomena but a religious one and that this strata of the middle class who cleave to social justice are a modern manifestation of what one might call the Puritan spirit.  Because I'm literally a communist!  One can see it, for example, in William Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, in which two knights, Sir Toby and Sir Andrew, are united with two members of the lower orders, Feste the Clown and Maria the Servant, who serves in the court of Olivia, who is a noblewoman, against one of the middling sort, Malvolio, who is described in the play as a kind of Puritan.  The play is set during the festive period of Christmas.  Let's watch a little bit.  What
a catawarning
to keep
here.  If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.  My lady's a Cataean.  We are politicians, malvolios, apegorams.
And three women, and three women, and three women.  Am I not consanguineous?
Am not I of her blood?  Tilly-billy ladies.
Oh, but surely the knight's an admirable fooling.  Aye, he does well enough if he be disposed, but so do I too.  He does it with a better grace, but I do it more naturally.

Oh, the 20th of December.  My true love said to me, my God.  My God.  The love of God, priest.  My masters, are you mad, or what are you?  Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?  Do you make an ill house of my lady's house, that you squeak out your cosiest catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice?  Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
We did keep time, sir, in our catches.  Neck up!

Toby, I must be round with you.  My lady bade me tell you that though she harbors you as her kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders.  If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house.  If not, and it would please you to take leave of her, she's very willing to bid you farewell.  Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs begun.  He could, sir.  Toby.  His eyes do show his days are almost done.  Is it even so?  But I will never die.
Sir Toby, there you lie.  This is much credit to him.  So I did him go and spare.
not.  No!  No, no, you dare not.  How do you say you lie?
And any more than a steward.
Listen, I think because thou art virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ales.

Yes, Spice and Anne.  And ginger shall be hot in the mouth.  That is right.  Now this general attitude and spirit did not go away in the 1950s.  Indeed, it fueled the English Civil War and there was always a streak of it in the middle strata right through the Victorian period as well.  One can see it in the figure of Jeremy Corbyn himself, especially in the footage here.  He seems a prig and, well, a kind of Puritan.  especially when contrasted with the Falstaffian and Sir Toby-like figure of Boris Johnson.  One of the films that captures the essence of this sort of puritanical middle class and a personal favourite of mine is Mike Lee's Nuts in May.  Let me play you a little clip in which Keith Pratt and his wife Candice Marie have invited the hapless PE student Ray over to their tent ostensibly to take a photograph for them.  But it ends up becoming more like a lecture.  Take a look.
Oh, I saw you doing your exercises this morning.  I follow the Royal Canadian Air Force system myself.
Oh, yeah.
You have a system?
Well, I was just doing basic sort of rugby circuit training, really, you know.
Yes, but is it a system?
What do you mean, system?
Well, is it tabulated?  Do you time yourself?
Well, you can do if you want to, you know, but I was just loosening up.
Oh, I see.  You see my maximum-minimum thermometer over there?
Oh, yeah.

One of my instruments for logging the weather.  Another one over here.  This is a portable barometer.  A bit like a travelling clock, really.  It's silly in the middle of the night.  if you wake up, want to know the time, turn over and all you find out is whether it's fair or foul.
Take sugar, eh?
Yeah, two, please.
It's only brown sugar.  Is that all right?
Sure, as long as it's sweet, you know.

We don't keep the killer whites in our tent, do we, Canis Marine?  No.  Flour, white sugar.  A lot of people don't realise the body doesn't need sugar, as most people know it.  It breaks down carbohydrates into polysaccharides, which are natural sugars more easily absorbed by the body.
We can get our sugar from fruit and honey.
Glucose, sucrose and frucrose.  Did you know that, Ray?
Yeah.
Oh.  Do you, er, eat meat, Ray?
Oh, yeah, I love meat.  It's great.
Alice, Marie and I don't take it, do we?
No.  Keith and I believe that it's inhumane to kill animals for food.
Man is not a carnivore.  He's naturally a frugivore.  He eats fruit and nuts.
It's interesting to note, Ray, that a carnivore's jaws move up and down like this.  But a plant-eating animal and human being's jaws also swing from side to side like that.

Yes, and a carnivore has a very short intestine suitable for carrying the putrefying meat through the system.  Whereas a human being has a very long intestine not suitable for that function at all.  No wonder so many people have cancer of the bowel.
Well, I don't know.  A lot of athletes and sportsmen eat meat.  They seem to do all right by it.
Oh, yes, but it's a well-known fact, Ray, that a world champion marathon runner was a vegetarian, and he reckoned this has improved his running.

Yes, a lot of famous people in history have been vegetarians.  Leonardo da Vinci, Malcolm Muggeridge, and God said, "'Behold, I have given unto thee every herb-bearing seed "'which is upon the face of the  earth.'".  And every tree in which is the fruit of every tree yielding seed, to you it shall be for meat.  Genesis, chapter 1, verse 29.
Do you mind if I smoke?
Well...
You do what you want to do, Rave.
It's just that Keith and I believe that smoking damages your health.
Well, never mind.
You see, Rave, you can't see the damage that it's doing.  But if I could take one of your lungs now and put it on the table in front of you and cut it in half, I think you'd be absolutely horrified.
You have to remember that the air polluted by one person has to be breathed by everybody else.  Pollution is one of the great disasters of our age.
I see running a car doesn't bother you much.
Oh, I only use it for getting from A to B.

As Nuts in May progresses, we see more and more of the brittleness of Keith and Candice Marie's worldview.  Things come to a head when a pair of working class Brummies, that's people from Birmingham for you American viewers, illegally start a fire on the campsite.  Watch what happens.
You're being very silly, you know, because if you do light an open fire, then you're going to get thrown off the campsite.

Now, don't be silly!  How will you mind your own bleeding business?  It is my business!  My business is to protect the life of the countryside and our heritage!  Now, you don't seem to be aware of those things, so I'm advising you as to the extent of your responsibilities!  You shouldn't be breaking those branches and you shouldn't be making a fire!
I've got you, Monk.

Now, I don't want to get you into trouble, but if you go on with this, I shall have to go and tell Miss Beale.  You can tell her you're bleeding well, like.  All right, if that's the way you want it.  And Miss Beale doesn't seem to be around, and so I'm assuming responsibility.  I bet you didn't look for her, did you?  Yes, I did, and she's not there.  Now, stop what you're doing.  No, but I believe now you think you are.  I'm a good citizen who's aware of his responsibilities.  You're a bloody comedian, mate.  No, I'm not.  Now, stop what you're doing.  No, look, I paid my money.  You don't know.  Why don't you come telling me what to do?  Oh, I've got every right.  I have the power to arrest you if I wanted to.  Now, stop making that fire.  No, but every citizen has the right to arrest another citizen who's breaking the law, now be told.  What law am I breaking?  You're breaking the laws of the campsite and the laws of the country code.  Now, I don't want to have to use force.  Do I?  Put the stick down.
No.  Oh, come on.

What were you gonna do about it, didn't I?  Just put the stick down.  Just leave it.  You wanna fight, I'm gonna... Look, be calm!  If you touch me, I'm gonna bloody kill you.  Look, I don't want to fight you.  I just want to tell you that you shouldn't...
Finger, leave it alone!

I just want you to stop making the fire and stop breaking those branches.  Come on, Finger, leave it alone.  Come on, it's me.  Come on.  No, no, I'm not going to.  Get away from me or I'll knock your head off!  Get back, I'm warning you!  I'll knock your head off!  I'll knock your head off!  You come on in if you want to fight!  Come on then, do you want to fight?  I'll give you one then!  Come on!  Come on, let's fight!
Come on, I'll knock your head off!

Don't touch me, mate!  Oh, finger just slipped!  Oh, put it down!  Come on then!  Come on!  What about it, eh?  I'll knock your head off!  Come on then!  Look, you get your geezer over here, so I'll kick this bloody table over.
Keith!  Keith, she's got a knife and she's going to kick the table over!  Put the stick down, you bastard!  I'll fucking kill you!  Keith!  Come on then!
Come on!  Finger!  Get away from there!  Get back!  You get back!  Finger!  Finger, get over here!  Oh, shut up!
